--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>
wrot=
e:

Peter, I think a key issue is the one you raise about the raw CPPN not
=
being able to effectively quantify density:

> 
> See, they are excellent a=
t generating patterns in space. But in a 
> realistic physics world, the hi=
gh-level patterns have to be 
> interpreted in the appropriate way. The raw=
 CPPN output has just 
> everything needed, but the pattern itself cannot *=
effectively* 
> describe quantity/density of matter. And more, because subs=
trates and 
> physics bodies are structures with finite size, all these pat=
terns 
> have to be interpreted in a special way, completely different than=
 a 
> simple mapping from a higher-dimensional space. This is because an 
>=
 isomorphic mapping like in HyperNEAT does not contain information 
> about=
 quantity of structural components, i.e. if I query for 100 links 
> in 4D =
or 6D they are still 100 links mapped back to 2D for example. 
> And I am b=
asically allowed to query for links/points anywhere in  
> space, which I c=
an't do in physics. 
> 

You make a good argument, and I understand the con=
cerns, but I think
this is still an open question right now.  I am still no=
t sure about
it.   However, I do think it is good that we are now consideri=
ng this
issue.  It's very interesting that density and connectivity can be
=
thought about as potentially two separate problems that both relate to
neur=
oevolution in different ways.  In my view, that is one of the most
interest=
ing things to emerge from HyperNEAT.

In any case, I am certainly intereste=
d in the density maps that
your approaches come up with.

ken
